centromeres Kinetochore Microtubule

centromere: histone CENH3 -> H3

  • Heterochromatin in Srosophlia melanogaster: 420kb
  • The C-banding patterns of human chromosome: 0.25~5Mb a satellite

Centromeres are evolutionary junkyards of eukaryotic genomes:

  1. Centomeres in most higher eukaryotic …
  2. do not contain genes
  3. cross over is completely suppressed

The brith and death of centromeres:

  • joint
  • moved from satellite, old still there

sentromere repositioning during evolution:

  • no rearranging.

Neocentromere-mediateed centromere evolution:

  • somthing in between?

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Work~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

CentO satellite repeat in rice replace:

  • range from 60kb - 4Mb

potato centromeres:

  • sequencing reads mapping peak
  • those with no peak: satellate repeat 1.5Mb

The starnge patato centormeres: 1. 6 satellites rep unique 2. 5 centormeres dose not contain satellites repeat 3. one centormere contain both …

An evolutionary new centromere will have battle with the original centeomere in the populations

Different haplotypes of Potato centromere 2:

  • Atzimba VS Kennebec VS Kerr’s Pink

How an evolutionary new centromere eventually prevails?

  • Human neroecntromeres are small(90-469kb) VS normal centromers(540-1700kb)
  • Cen2 in Oats(4Mb) > Cen2 in Maize(B73)(2Mb): expanded in one direction @ same place
  • CENH3 nucleosomes appear to be incompatible to transcription -> No genes.
  • alter the transcription
  • may impact the recombination of many genes in the centromeric regions
  • may impact the epigenetic modification

take home 1. centromeres evolved from neocentromeres 2. evolve slowly or change from “repeatless” pattern to “repeat-based” pattern in a sudden fasion 3. Neocentromere activation will affect transcription and recombintation of gene located in teh centromeric and pericentromeric regions.

if a centromeres longer than 10Mb it’s not stable.
